newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Game maker offers virtual war in Taiwan-Japan row.
newsitem.headline: Game maker offers virtual war in Taiwan-Japan row.

text.p: Taiwanese eager to challenge Tokyo's controversial claim to a chain of islands in the East China Sea now can take matters in their own hands -- by waging war with Japan in a virtual-reality computer game.

"The game starts with a small clash between Taiwan and Japan over the Diaoyu islands and China joins in as tensions escalate," Liu Chao-yi, programme designer at Taiwan's Software World, said on Tuesday.
"Whoever wins the game gets sovereignty in the Diaoyus."
Taiwan, China and Japan all claim the uninhabited islands, called the Diaoyus in Chinese and the Senkakus in Japanese.
A long-dormant dispute over them flared up in July when Japanese rightists built a lighthouse on one of the islands to assert Tokyo's claim.
The computer game will retail for T$300 (US$11) when it is launched next week in Taiwan.
Sensing a business opportunity on the other side of the dispute, Software World will market the game in Japan as well.

It is not the company's first foray into simulation of Taiwan's real-life diplomatic crises. The south Taiwan firm has already marketed a game that simulated a Taiwan-China missile crisis based on intimidating war games mounted by Beijing in waters near Taiwan in late 1995 and early 1996.
